repnme.cdata!:
India - States' Road Infrastructure
            Development Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the States' Road
            Infrastructure Development Technical Assistance Project for
            India is rated satisfactory. The main objective was
            achieved. Sixteen states ended up meeting entry conditions
            and became participants in the project, compared to fifteen
            potential candidate states identified at appraisal.
            Activities related to institutional development were carried
            out, but they were intended to help prepare institutional
            development changes rather than carry out reforms. A key
            indicator of the project's sustainability is the
            satisfactory progress, with just minor exceptions, in the
            implementation of the several follow-on state road projects
            that were originated by the technical assistance (TA)
            project. The following lessons were learned: The risks of
            multi-state projects should be carefully assessed during
            preparation, especially due to the greater complexity of
            supervision required. Entry conditions requiring commitment
            to reforms are useful when such commitments are formalized
            vis-a-vis of both the central government and the Bank.
            Resettlement and rehabilitation policies are an issue which
            can cause conflict especially in states which are confronted
            with Bank regulations for the first time.

7377431.trustfund:
TF026215-FINANCING OF AUSAID SECONDMENTS,TF034775-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS,TF036177-INDIA - A STUDY OF MANAGEMENT
            OF ROADS IMPACTS ON SENSITIVE ENV,TF036231-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS

repnme.cdata!:
India - States' Road Infrastructure
            Development Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though the institutional development
            impact is only modest. The positive lessons learned convey
            that technical assistance (TA) is most effective in
            supporting policy, and institutional reforms, provided these
            reforms are linked to future investment support, i.e.,
            incentives such as access to external investment, to prod
            positive responsiveness by State road agencies, including
            the serious application of environmental and social laws,
            and regulations, procurement, and financial management. As
            well, having the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) a
            non-sector specific body as the central implementing agency,
            was successful in delivering a TA project to time, quality,
            and cost constraints. Moreover, the adoption by
            participating states of a standardized project
            identification and preparation framework, allowed the
            efficient delivery of multiple project preparation, both for
            the states, the DEA, and the Bank itself. Other lessons to
            be addressed in the future suggest the development of
            performance indicators to measure project results on
            institutional impacts, including more formal mechanisms to
            involve non-government stakeholders in the preparation of
            institutional, and policy reform elements. Likewise,
            requirements for investment projects preparation in meeting
            environmental, and social safeguards, need to be applied on
            a consistent basis, to minimize clients' uncertainty,
            while, the states' experience with the standard terms
            of reference (TORs) for project coordinating consultancy
            services, proved mixed; rather the secondment of road agency
            staff to the project coordinating consultants, or explicit
            TORs that specify the required staff skills'
            development outcomes, should be practiced.

5082980.trustfund:
TF036177-INDIA - A STUDY OF MANAGEMENT
            OF ROADS IMPACTS ON SENSITIVE ENV,TF034775-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS,TF036231-INDIA - NATIONAL HIGHWAYS,TF026215-FINANCING OF AUSAID SECONDMENTS

repnme.cdata!:
India - States' Road Infrastructure
            Development Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the
            States' Road Infrastructure Development Technical
            Assistance Project is to strengthen policy based efforts by
            individual States towards effective reforms in the
            provision, financing and maintenance of road infrastructure,
            while assisting their preparation of high-priority quality
            road infrastructure investments aimed at Bank financing. The
            project will, over five years, finance technical assistance
            activities in three project components: a) project
            preparation and implementation support; b) policy support
            and institutional development; and c) project management.
